user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.2 is: A for loop shall be well-formed.
The three clauses of a for statement are the:
1. First clause shall be empty or an expression whose set the value of the loop counter or define and intialize the loop counter.
2. Second clause shall be an expression that has no persistent side effects, and shall use the loop counter and optionally loop control flags, and shall not use any other object that is modified in the for loop body.
3.Third clause shall be an expression whose modify only the value of the loop counter, and shall not use objects that are modified in the for loop body.
4. There shall only be one loop counter in a for loop, which shall not be modified in for loop body. A loop control flag is defined as single identifier denoting an object with Boolean type that is used in the second clause. The behaviour of a for loop body includes the behaviour of any functions called within that statement. 
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_CondVarWait_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_CondVarWait_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int                                status;
    OS_impl_condvar_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_condvar_table, *token);

    /*
     * note that because pthread_cond_wait is a cancellation point, this needs to
     * employ the same protection that is in the binsem module.  In the event that
     * the thread is canceled inside pthread_cond_wait, the mutex will be re-acquired
     * before the cancellation occurs, leaving the mutex in a locked state.
     */
    pthread_cleanup_push(OS_Posix_CondVarReleaseMutex, &impl->mut);
    status = pthread_cond_wait(&impl->cv, &impl->mut);
    pthread_cleanup_pop(false);

    if (status != 0)
    {
        return OS_ERROR;
    }

    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_CondVarWait_Impl:
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
...
OS_impl_condvar_internal_record_t OS_impl_condvar_table[OS_MAX_CONDVARS]
...
typedef struct
{
    pthread_mutex_t mut;
    pthread_cond_t  cv;
} OS_impl_condvar_internal_record_t
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
static void OS_Posix_CondVarReleaseMutex(void *mut)
{
    pthread_mutex_unlock(mut);
}
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
...
#define OS_ERROR (-1)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I inspected the target function OS_CondVarWait_Impl and the additional definitions provided. There are no for statements present in the supplied code fragments (no occurrence of the 'for' keyword). Therefore MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.2 (requirements for well-formed for loops) cannot be violated within the shown code. 

Notes/reasoning: 
- The only loop-relevant construct in the function is a call to OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET, but its definition was not provided in the snippets. If that macro expands to a for loop, or if any called function (for example any macros or functions referenced but not shown) contains a for loop, those definitions should be examined separately. 
- pthread_cleanup_push/pthread_cleanup_pop and the pthread_cond_wait call are not for loops and are not relevant to Rule 14.2.

Conclusion: No suspicious code fragments for Rule 14.2 exist in the supplied code. If you want, provide the definition of OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET and the implementations of any called functions/macros so they can be checked for for-loops that might need investigation.
